Biology.Abiotic Factors: physiscal & chemical factors in the environment that are nonliving; determines the types of plants & animals that will establish themselves and thrive
Biology.Active Transport: cell uses energy to move individual molecules across cell membrane for balance
Biology.Amphibians: delicate and permeable skin; oviparous; start out with gills, then have lungs as adults
Biology.Anaphase: third phase of mitosis; 1\/2 of chromosomes goes one way and the other way
Biology.Apical Meristem: shoot that helps the plant increase in length
Biology.Arthropods: joint-footed animals; have exoskeletons; molt; several jointed walking legs; nervous system; they metemorph; open circulatory system; SPIDERS, CENTIPEDES
Biology.Bacteria: enter through break of skin; contaminated food\/water; inhalation; reproduces rapidly; produces toxins that kill host tissues; BUBONIC PLAGUE
Biology.Bad bacteria: killed by the penicillin developed from a fungus
Biology.Biochemistry: the study of substances and processes occurring in living things; diseases and drugs to cure them
Biology.Biophysics: Applies the laws of physics to explain the phenomena of biology
Biology.Biotic Factors: living components of the environment that affect the ecology of an area; predator\/prey, producer\/consumer
Biology.Carbohydrates: compounds made of hydrogen, carbon, oxygen
Biology.Carbon: element found in all living things
Biology.Cell: basic organizational unit of all living things; unique to each organism; helps organisms grow & survive
Biology.Cellulose: makes up cells and tissues of plants; most common organic materials
Biology.Chelonia: members have shells; live in climates that are warm enough; found near water or on land; TURTLES, TORTOISES
Biology.Chlorophyll: responsible for the absorption of light to provide energy for photosynthesis; the energy breaks down water into hydrogen & oxygen to form ATP molecules
Biology.Chloroplasts: makes plants green; food producers of a plant cell; has 2 membranes that contain and protect inner parts; have chlorophyll, DNA, ribosomes, and enzymes
Biology.Chromatin: Clusters of DNA, RNA, and proteins in the nucleus of a cell
Biology.Chromosomes: structures inside the nucleus of a cell made up primarily of DNA and proteins; carry genes; humans= 46 chromosomes
Biology.Circulatory System: provides fresh oxygen through blood; oxygen carried by this system
Biology.Conifers: trees that thrive in northern latitudes & have cones; PINE, CEDAR;EVERGREENS; very tall and strong
Biology.Consumers: eats plants(herbivores), eats herbivores(carnivores), eats both (omnivores)
Biology.Cotyledons: seed leaf or food package for the developing plant
Biology.Crocodilia: can grow large; alligators & crocodiles; found near water
Biology.Cycads: sturdy plants with big, waxy fronds that make them look like ferns or palms; survive in harsh conditions
Biology.Decomposer: eats dead things and returns nutrients to soil
Biology.Dicot: seeds w\/ 2 cotyledons; everyday flowers w\/ 4-5 petals and extremely complex leaves w\/ veins; ROSES, SUNFLOWERS
Biology.Digestive System: mouth & pharynx used to swallow food\/drink; breathe
Biology.Ecology: relationship of living organisms to their environments
Biology.Emphysema: smoking tobacco; destroys tissue in lungs
Biology.Endoskeleton: inside the body; made up of bones; supports body, provides framework; protects inner organs
Biology.Energy: flows in one direction- from the sun, through photosynthetic organisms, algae, then herbivores, carnivores and decomposers.
Biology.Eukaryotic cells: have nucleus; controls eating, movement, reproduction
Biology.FIsh: most primitive; group from which all other groups evolved; breathe with gills, cold-blooded; fins and scales; oviparous
Biology.Flowers: attract organisms that can help pollinate the plant & distribute seeds; some also produce fruit
Biology.Food chain: series of events that happens when one organism consumes another to survive
Biology.Freshwater Invertebrate: lives in lakes and rivers; WORMS AT BOTTOM OF WATER
Biology.Fungi: feeds on healthy tissues; sends rootlike tendrils into tissues; RINGWORM
Biology.Fungi Kingdom: no chlorophyll; doesn't make their own food; reproduces asexually or sexually; made up of filaments; MUSHROOMS; eukaryotic; HAS CELL WALL
Biology.Genetics: how characteristics are transmitted from one generation to another; Gregor Mendel
Biology.Genotype: genetic makeup of an organism\/individual; determines hair color
Biology.Good bacteria: helps plants absorb nitrogen needed for growth
Biology.Gregor Mendel: father of genetics; discovered the 3 laws of heredity that explain how genetics work(law of segregation, law of independent assortment, law of dominance)
Biology.Gymnosperms: plants w\/ vascular systems and seeds but NO FLOWERS
Biology.Hershey-Chase Experiment(1952): Alfred Hershey & Martha Chase; showed that DNA is the genetic material that transfers info for inheritance; used a virus that infects bacteria to infect E-Coli
Biology.Heterotrophs: organisms that cannot make their own food
Biology.Histology: study of TISSUES OF PLANTS AND CELLS
Biology.Hunters(Predators): carnivorous; territorial; equipped to capture; use minimum amt. of energy for each capture; never kill more than they can eat
Biology.Interphase: normal state of the cell; resting stage between divisions
Biology.Leaves: site for photosynthesis; connected to the rest of the plant by a vascular system
Biology.Lipids: insoluble in water; 3 types: fat, phospholipids, estrogen
Biology.Locomotion: moving from one place to place in the environment
Biology.Mammals: highly evolved vertebrates; fur; warm-blooded; viviparous-give birth to live young; four-legged; live on ground, water, or fly
Biology.Marine Invertebrate: lives in oceans and seas; JELLYFISH; OCTOPUS
Biology.Marsupials: give birth to live young; babies mature in pouches; KANGAROOS
Biology.Metaphase: second phase of mitosis; different pieces align themselves for split; DNA lines up; centrioles send out tubules to connect to centromere
Biology.Microbes: smallest,simplest and most abundant organisms; can be harmful or helpful; microscope required to see; BACTERIA\/FUNGI; can eat other things or make their own food
Biology.Mitochondria: Powerhouse of the cell; takes in nutrients, breaks them down, creates energy; found in all eukaryotic cells; found in cytoplasm of cell; PRODUCES ATP
Biology.Mitosis: duplication of a cell and all of its parts; has a life cycle of 5 phases
Biology.Mold: zygote fungi that reproduces w\/ a stalk, but releases zygospheres
Biology.Moneran Kingdom: prokaryotes; just 1 chromosome; reproduces asexually; has flagella; either BACTERIA or blue-green algae
Biology.Monocots: simple flowering plants; GRASSES; have 3 petals on their flowers; their leaves are long strands
Biology.Monotremes: lay eggs; first mammals closely related to reptiles; DUCK-BILLED PLATYPUS
Biology.Mushrooms: fungus that lives as a group of strands underground that decompose leaves
Biology.Mutations: random genetic changes; can be beneficial and result in a different organism over time
Biology.Natural Selection: mechanism of evolution; Charles Darwin- said evolution is a slow,gradual process
Biology.Nervous System: divided into 2 parts; central nervous system & peripheral nervous system; SENSES AND ACTIONS- senses something & acts upon it; interacts w\/ every other system in the body
Biology.Nuclear Envelope: surrounds nucleus; allows RNA & proteins to pass through
Biology.Nucleic Acids: large molecules composed of large number of simpler molecules
Biology.Organelles: groups of complex molecules that help a cell survive; larger the cell, more organelles it needs to live
Biology.Organology: study of TISSUES ORGANIZED INTO ORGANS
Biology.Peripheral Nervous System (PNS): the sensory and motor neurons that connect the CNS to the rest of the body
Biology.Phenotype: external manifestation of the genotype; actual color of the hair
Biology.Photosynthesis: energy from the sun hits a chloroplast & the chlorophyll uses the energy to combine carbon dioxide & water to make sugar and oxygens
Biology.Placental Mammals: give birth from females' placenta to live young; may be able to walk immediately or need to be carried; dominant form of mammals; WHALES & DOLPHINS, TIGERS
Biology.Plant & Animal Cell Similarities: eukaryotic; nucleus; reproduction process; cell membranes; cytoplasm; microtubules; vacuoles
Biology.Plant Kingdom: all multi-celled organisms; have chlorophyll; make their own food; reproduces asexually or sexually; GREEN ALGAE; cell walls have cellulose and lignin
Biology.Prey: herbivores; hide in nests\/caves, camoflauge, warning coloration; shells
Biology.Producers: plants & vegetables; take energy from the sun; make food for themselves through photosynthesis
Biology.Prophase: first phase of mitosis; duplicates everything
Biology.Proteins: make up almost 1\/2 dry weight of animal bodies; make up muscle fibers
Biology.Protist Kingdom: simplest eukaryotes; true nucleus surrounded by membranes that separated from cytoplasm; one-celled, no complex tissues; ALGAE
Biology.Regulation: coordinating life activities through nervous & endocrine systems
Biology.Reproduction and growth: producing more of one's own kind and growing from birth-adulthood
Biology.Reptiles and birds: very hard, horn-like scales; feathers; oviparous; have a cloaca; cold-blooded and warm-bloode
Biology.Respiratory System: exchanges gases with the environment; nose, mouth, pharynx, trachea, 2 lungs; brings oxygen into body & expel carbon dioxide; inhale viruses, bacteria, dangerous chemicals
Biology.Root hairs: fuzzy root extensions that help w\/ absorption of water & nutrients
Biology.Roots: pull water and minerals from soil or water; go deep into the ground to reach water, support and stabilize trees; CARROTS, TURNIPS; classified as primary & lateral
Biology.Skeletal System: interacts w\/ muscular system to help body move; interacts w\/ circulatory system to help produce white & red blood cells
Biology.Stems: transport food & water and acts as support structures
Biology.T-2: small piece of DNA enclosed in a protein coating; DNA contains phosphorus & protein coating contains sulfur
Biology.Telophase: fourth phase of mitosis; cell membrane closes & spits cell into 2 pieces
Biology.Terrestrial Invertebrates: live on dry ground; INSECTS' breathes through trachea; delivers oxygen into tissues
Biology.Transport: circulation of essential materials like nutrients, cells, hormones through veins
Biology.Transport Holes: proteins that help certain molecules and ions move in and out of the cell
Biology.Viruses: airborne; contaminated food, water; infected tissues; takes over cell's protein synthesis mechanism; kills host cells; AIDS

biofilm.3 model behaviors: B. subtilis: bet hedging \nM. xanthus: community behavior\nC. albicans: infectious biofilms
biofilm.C albicans characteristics: dimorphic fungus \nmost common human fungal pathogen\nmodel for infectious biofilm
biofilm.Fibrin: coagulase-mediated conversion of fibrinogen to fibrin
biofilm.M. xanthus characteristics: G-\nsingle species biofilm\nmodel for community behavior
biofilm.Pili: bind to N-glycans on apical surface of epithelial cells
biofilm.QS and pH: more basic in center\nless QS in the center

-virulent factors 
-lyse host cells
-surfactant qualities that promote biofilm dispersal
-accumulate amyloid aggregrates 
-60% of S. aureus secreted biomass

s aureus

biofilm.coagulase negative: usually commensals (S. epidermidis) but can also be pathogenic S. lugdenesis which means it doesn't need fibrin to form biofilm
biofilm.endocarditis most commonly caused by: IV drug, surgical infx, infx implant\/valve
biofilm.flagella: bind to heparan sulfate proteoglycans on basolateral surface of epithelial cells
biofilm.hypothesized benefit of rolling motion o: more SA of bacteria touches the surface
biofilm.immunoglycosides: immunoglycosides are positive so they can't get thru EPS
biofilm.p. aureus infection will have flat shape: low iron bc our bodies have nutritional immunity \n\nwhen theres pathogens our body will sequester metals away from the pathogens
biofilm.pel: protects against aminoglycoside antibiotics and promotes cell-to-cell interactions
biofilm.polysaccharide:
s. aureus
PNAG: poly N-acteylgucosamine 
PIA: polysaccharide intercellular adhesion 
PIA=PNAG=derivate of glucose and is produced by intracellular adhesion operon (icaADBC)

nutrient depletion 
creates zones of altered activity
outer layer absorb damage
persister cells
inner layers have more time to respond

attachment proteins
desiccation tolerance 
localized gradients
physical persistence
tolerance and resistance

biofilm.properties assisting with anti immune:
decreased penetration
decreased phagocytic capacity
quorum sensing
inactivation
impaired complement deposition
global response regulators
genetic switches

biofilm.triangle msha: no attachment pili \nWT roaming to orbital to nothing
biofilm.what kind of surface proteins does S. au: fibronectin-binding proteins w\/out conditioning film it can do autolysis
biofilm.which is faster growing immature or matu: immature\n*doesn't have tolerance so it needs to grow fast
